messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Fine-grained complexity of the list homomorphism problem: feedback vertex set and cutwidthThis work is supported by Polish National Science Centre grant no. 2018/31/D/ST6/00062.

Paper Abstract: For graphs G,H𝐺𝐻G,H, a homomorphism from G𝐺G to H𝐻H is an edge-preserving mapping from V​(G)𝑉𝐺V(G) to V​(H)𝑉𝐻V(H). In the list homomorphism problem, denoted by LHom(H𝐻H), we are given a graph G𝐺G, whose every vertex v𝑣v is equipped with a list L​(v)⊆V​(H)𝐿𝑣𝑉𝐻L(v)\subseteq V(H), and we need to determine whether there exists a homomorphism from G𝐺G to H𝐻H which additionally respects the lists L𝐿L. List homomorphisms are a natural generalization of (list) colorings. Very recently Okrasa, Piecyk, and Rzążewski [ESA 2020] studied the fine-grained complexity of the problem, parameterized by the treewidth of the instance graph G𝐺G. They defined a new invariant i∗​(H)superscript𝑖𝐻i^{*}(H), and proved that for every relevant graph H𝐻H, this invariant is the correct base of the exponent in the running time of any algorithm solving the LHom(H𝐻H) problem. In this paper we continue this direction and study the complexity of the problem under different parameterizations. As the first result, we show that i∗​(H)superscript𝑖𝐻i^{*}(H) is also the right complexity base if the parameter is the size of a minimum feedback vertex set of G𝐺G, denoted by fvs​(G)fvs𝐺\textrm{fvs}(G). In particular, for every relevant graph H𝐻H, the LHom(H𝐻H) problem • can be solved in time i∗​(H)fvs​(G)⋅|V​(G)|𝒪​(1)⋅superscript𝑖superscript𝐻fvs𝐺superscript𝑉𝐺𝒪1i^{*}(H)^{\textrm{fvs}(G)}\cdot|V(G)|^{\mathcal{O}(1)}, if a minimum feedback vertex set of G𝐺G is given, • cannot be solved in time (i∗​(H)−ε)fvs​(G)⋅|V​(G)|𝒪​(1)⋅superscriptsuperscript𝑖𝐻𝜀fvs𝐺superscript𝑉𝐺𝒪1(i^{*}(H)-\varepsilon)^{\textrm{fvs}(G)}\cdot|V(G)|^{\mathcal{O}(1)}, for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, unless the SETH fails. Then we turn our attention to a parameterization by the cutwidth ctw​(G)ctw𝐺\textrm{ctw}(G) of G𝐺G. Jansen and Nederlof [ESA 2018] showed that List k𝑘k-Coloring (i.e., LHom(Kksubscript𝐾𝑘K_{k})) can be solved in time 𝒪∗​(cctw​(G))superscript𝒪superscript𝑐ctw𝐺\mathcal{O}^{*}\left(c^{\textrm{ctw}(G)}\right) for an absolute constant c𝑐c, i.e., the base of the exponential function does not depend on the number of colors. Jansen asked whether this behavior extends to graph homomorphisms. As the main result of the paper, we answer the question in the negative. We define a new graph invariant m​i​m∗​(H)𝑚𝑖superscript𝑚𝐻mim^{*}(H), closely related to the size of a maximum induced matching in H𝐻H, and prove that for all relevant graphs H𝐻H, the LHom(H𝐻H) problem cannot be solved in time 𝒪∗​((m​i​m∗​(H)−ε)ctw​(G))superscript𝒪superscript𝑚𝑖superscript𝑚𝐻𝜀ctw𝐺\mathcal{O}^{*}\left((mim^{*}(H)-\varepsilon)^{\textrm{ctw}(G)}\right) for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, unless the SETH fails. In particular, this implies that there is no constant c𝑐c, such that for every odd cycle the non-list version of the problem can be solved in time 𝒪∗​(cctw​(G))superscript𝒪superscript𝑐ctw𝐺\mathcal{O}^{*}\left(c^{\textrm{ctw}(G)}\right). Finally, we generalize the algorithm of Jansen and Nederlof, so that it can be used to solve LHom(H𝐻H) for every graph H𝐻H; its complexity depends on ctw​(G)ctw𝐺\textrm{ctw}(G) and another invariant of H𝐻H, which is constant for cliques.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The Probabilistic Method, Third Edition",
        "Linear time algorithms for NP-hard problems restricted to partial k𝑘k-trees",
        "DP-colorings of graphs with high chromatic number",
        "Set partitioning via inclusion-exclusion",
        "Classes of graphs with bounded tree-width",
        "Combinatorial optimization on graphs of bounded treewidth",
        "Triangular factorization and inversion by fast matrix multiplication",
        "The exponential-time complexity of counting (quantum) graph homomorphisms",
        "List H𝐻H-coloring a graph by removing few vertices",
        "Complexity of Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k}-coloring in hereditary classes of graphs",
        "Graphs with small bandwidth and cutwidth",
        "Matrix multiplication via arithmetic progressions",
        "Tight lower bounds on graph embedding problems",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Descriptive complexity of list H-coloring problems in logspace: A refined dichotomy",
        "Correspondence coloring and its application to list-coloring planar graphs without cycles of lengths 4 to 8",
        "Space complexity of list H-colouring: a dichotomy",
        "The complexity of the list homomorphism problem for graphs",
        "Finding list homomorphisms from bounded-treewidth graphs to reflexive graphs: a complete complexity characterization",
        "List homomorphisms to reflexive graphs",
        "List homomorphisms and circular arc graphs",
        "Bi-arc graphs and the complexity of list homomorphisms",
        "Locally injective graph homomorphism: Lists guarantee dichotomy",
        "Exact algorithms for graph homomorphisms",
        "Some simplified NP-complete graph problems",
        "Cliquewidth III: the odd case of graph coloring parameterized by cliquewidth",
        "The core of a graph",
        "Graphs and homomorphisms",
        "On the complexity of H-coloring",
        "The dichotomy of list homomorphisms for digraphs",
        "The NP-completeness of edge-coloring",
        "Improved complexity results on k𝑘k-coloring Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t}-free graphs",
        "A generalization of the fast LUP matrix decomposition algorithm and applications",
        "On the complexity of k𝑘k-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Fine-grained parameterized complexity analysis of graph coloring problems",
        "Personal communication.",
        "Computing the chromatic number using graph decompositions via matrix rank",
        "On the hardness of approximating the chromatic number",
        "Finer tight bounds for coloring on clique-width",
        "Families of strongly projective graphs",
        "Strongly rigid graphs and projectivity",
        "Known algorithms on graphs of bounded treewidth are probably optimal",
        "Note on projective graphs",
        "Full complexity classification of the list homomorphism problem for bounded-treewidth graphs",
        "Fine-grained complexity of graph homomorphism problem for bounded-treewidth graphs",
        "Graph minors. II. algorithmic aspects of tree-width",
        "Exact algorithm for graph homomorphism and locally injective graph homomorphism",
        "New plain-exponential time classes for graph homomorphism",
        "Multiplying matrices faster than Coppersmith-Winograd"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Fine-grained complexity of the list homomorphism problem: feedback vertex set and cutwidthThis work is supported by Polish National Science Centre grant no. 2018/31/D/ST6/00062., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
